section.hand:
To M
r
Secretary Sep
t
10. 89

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 Septem
b
M
r
Secretary from M Bodly
Yt may please yo
r
H. to advertise my
LL.
of
e Counsell, that this day
I Rxd theyr letter of
e 30 of Auguste, wh
r
in they require me to move
the
generall States
to take some speedy order for the repairing of
e
fortifica
o
ns of
Oostende,
howbeit for that the Deputies of
Holland
are
gon from hence to
Count Maurice
, there wilbe no meeting of
e rest till
they shall returne, for whom we looke ev
r
y houre & at theyr next assembly
I will signify that unto them. w
ch
I have Rxd in charge & c
r
tify theyr
answer. This bearer hath made me acquainted w
th
such letters &
effect
request
as he hath bin moved to sollicite for those of
Frise.
But for mine owne
te I see no likelehood of any good that wilbe
don either for them or for any of those els where
t
stand uppon
like termes w
th
these countreys except a finall conclusion be taken betweene
her
Ma
ty
& them, for
e according of all thing
in question, or els
that yt will please her Hig
nes
to disavow by publick acte these two
last yeares muteneyes in sondry places. W
ch
they say have all bin
raised upon p
r
tence of doing
s
vice to her Ma
ty
. As touching
those offers that have bin made by some of
Harlingen.
as likewise
by some others els where of
e Province of [Phrise], who as he doth
signify unto mee desire nothing more then to surrender up all into
hir Ma
tyes
hand
, I can not say any thing because I neither
know
e
ties, nor theyr strength, but there ar many such
courtesyes, w
ch
ar often proposed in communica
o
n unto mee, & I have
by all probability to bee but motions of discontented
sons, who see
not
fectly into
e state of theyr affaires. & cannot any way
forme
as they will seem to
myse. Conc
r
ning
e practiz w
th
those of
Groeninghen,
w
ch
wilbe also im
ted by this bearer to yo
r
H. I can
say but littell not knowing thorouly
e state of
e Towne, theyr
[affectyons] to hir Ma
ty
, or dislike of
e Spaniard nevertheles
upon this occasyon I have had some conference heer w
th
a speciall
freind & one well acquainted w
th
e affaires of those quarters, who
doth hold yt very likely, to take good effect, & will give me
farder informa
o
n yf her Ma
ty
wilbe pleased to harken to
e motion
Count William of Frise
hath bin heer of late & c
o
ferred w
th
e States
about
e stopping of
e traffique & cariadge of vittuals to
e
Towne of Gronighen, w
ch
he hath proposed as a thing
t
may easily
be effected, unles
e Ennemy [.] against yt w
th
very great forces.
Wh
r
uppon w
th
some others that ar deputed from
e generall states &
e
Counsell of State
he ys gon to Count Maurice to confer & conclude
how to execute his purpose. Above all mens expectation
by gods miraculous working, the Ennemy having all thing
redy to passe
e Wael in
Bommel
mutined on
e suddayn as I
signifyed in my last to yo
r
H. & immediatly after at
[Middleburgh]
not far from
nieumeghen
./ 20 ensignes of Italians were passed
e Maese, but
e Spaniard
wold not follow; & now agayne
very lately at
Huesden,
ther hath growen som farder alteration
among
e souldiers, as th
r
uppon ther ar so many de
ted & in such sort
fol.115v
as
e garrison of
e Towne hath found meanes to Rx in
victuals & to send into
e Camp. What course wilbe taken
by
e Ennemy uppon yt we do not yet und
r
stand.
But yt is thought they shalbe satisfied, & then emploied
toward
Berck,
ther being alredy de
ted toward
those
quarters, 800 footemen, nev
r
theles we ar in good hope
t
they wilbe p
r
vented by 600 horse w
ch
e
Count Neuenar
hath sent from
Rees
to revictuall
e Towne wherof
we attend ev
r
y hour to know
e successe. Of
e Brutes
that ar heer of
e
Governo
r
of Cambrey
I have signifyed
nothing to yo
r
H. because they are wholly unc
r
taine, nev
r
theles
yt ys gen
r
ally thought
t
he hath neither as yet [declared]
him self to
e
Frenche K
. nor for
e Spaniard. And yt is
adv
r
tised hither at this p
nt
that
Parma
hath sent c
r
tayne
forces toward
France
thorough
Cambresy.
w
ch
for
t
in their
passadge
[t] wasted
e countrey were fought w
th
all & put to
e woorse by c
r
tain troupes w
ch
Mons
r
Baligny sent
out of
Cambray.
Mons
r
de la Thuillerie
e
French Embassado
r
ys gon from
Ambsterdam
to
Hamborc[h]
having Rxd such answer as I write in my former,
e loane
of 30000 [symbol for crowns] to be deliverd w
th
in 6 weekes, or 2 monethes
at
e uttermost after
e Rxt of
e French K. obliga
o
n
to be repaied w
th
in 12 monethes after he shalbe establyshed
in his Kingdome. there ar appointed from hence to go in embassie
Mons
r
de Brederode
e second brother.
Mons
r
Sylla
pensioner of Ambsterdam &
Mons
r
de la Pree
theyr last
agent in Fraunce whom they purpose to leave resydent behinde
These 3 ar all of Holland, w
ch
is not greatly liked by
e
oth
r
provinces, w
ch
desire to send also some of
eir owne. Yt is
also sayd
t
Count Maurice will send as from him self
Justinus
his brother wheare
e States ar as yet unwilling
alleadging sondry reasons but misdouting indeed as yt is
secretly spoken least ther should some practises be set
a foote betwene
e King &
e Count to
e p
r
vitie of these
Provinces.
